I learned a lot from field trips.

I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:

Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Timothy and he was incredible

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Tim did a fantastic job. When the time comes that he is going on the job market, Yale should pursue him vigorously.
Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Tim was great. Accessible, open minded, friendly, bright. We were lucky to have him.

Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Tim did a fantastic job of translating some difficult concepts and drawing out what was most useful in a conversation. Without him I think we would have been confused for much longer in the semester.
Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Tim is a fantastic TA. He is a great facilitator and complements Susan well.
Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Tim was an excellent TA-- he explained the material extremely well, and made the course a really amazing experience. I learned a tremendous amount from him.

Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Best TF I've had, hands down. Strengths: able to articulate very complex and abstract ideas effectively. Very responsive to meeting, supporting students. Thoughtful about pedagogy. Interesting guy. Weaknesses: not many. Maybe does a little too much recapping and summarizing of what others' said (though many times this came in very handy)

Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Strengths: Tim is patient and open, and gets very excited about students grasping new and unfamiliar concepts. He is a tremendous guide and facilitator, and pushes students to critically challenge themselves in academic pursuits.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Q15: This is the most valuable course taught at FES.

My best course at F&ES. Relevant to everyone who wants to better understand what's happening in the world and what they believe. This is what I wanted to find at this school and I'm so glad that in my 4th semester I finally found it. Dr. Clark is a great asset to this school - her pedagogy is effective and transformative. Thanks!

This class will teach you how to think not what to think. it is a departure from standard learning and much in need in our education system. a complete shame that it is not going to be available at FES for longer as it really is revolutionary and essential for what FES purports to do. This class is about how to approach the multi dimensional problems that exist. it does not pretend to give answers, only tools. it is wonderful.

The content of this course is unlike anything that I have experienced in my conservation career. Because of this, I have a new approach to dealing with an entire range of issues in conservation and beyond. Dr. Clark operates on a higher level than most people that I have ever interacted with. At the same time, she is inviting and encouraging as students try to grasps with some unorthodox ideas. I would recommend students from across FES to become familiar with the framework that is taught in this class. Doing so will provide students and professionals to take new, more pragmatic approaches to conservation in the hopes that advances in this field could be realized. I have continued to study the concepts taught in this class beyond the end of the semester, something I could scarcely say for other courses I have taken at FES. This course changed my way of thinking at a foundational level, and I will be a better leader in my field because of it.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The concepts taught in this course are critically important and are being taught no where else at this school.

I really enjoyed the group projects for this course. It really allowed us to dive into using and applying the framework. I would have been a lot more confused about the framework and how to use it if I did not have this opportunity to apply it to this project and have a group to discuss it with. I also loved hearing from the guest speakers and learn how they were using the framework. What I found most interesting is how they were able to subtly use the framework in conventional terms. This seem very practical and will be useful to us as we graduate. I also really appreciated how willing Susan was to meet outside of class to just chat. Having a professor who was so willing to have a fun conversation (whether it was related to class or not) was really meaningful.
Field trip was invaluable
The field trip was great - I learned a lot.
In-class dialogue

The field trip was an incredible opportunity to learn from others, myself, and my colleagues. There was a tangible project as well as opportunities to figure out what conservation really is and how I want to fit into it. Good discussions too.

Very well designed and executed by the teachers. The field trip opened my eyes to what people are thinking out there in the working world. The perfect experience to make sense of what can be a fairly abstract framework. This course's material is relevant to my own life in so many ways.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: It would have been great if group presentations could have happened at different times over the course of the semester. For example, it would have been really useful to have had the context group go early on so that other groups could have more effectively incorporated the context group's work into their own.

The expectations for many of the assignments were not always made clear. For instance we were not quite sure who we were writing our chapter for or exactly what it should contain. My only recommendation for improving this course would be to make expectations a bit clearer.
The information felt repetitive towards the middle of the class. The field trip provided a refreshed perspective.

The assignments were sometimes a little unclear (in terms of expectations). I think the readings could be classified in terms of recommended and required. I loved them, but they could be selected a little more judiciously, perhaps
At times, the material could seem to have been repeated week after week, but this also helped to reinforce some of the key concepts.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Yes, very effective. I loved how much facilitated discussion this course had. I wish every course could have included that.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This course has opened my eyes to so many things I didn't realize I had my eyes closed to. I know see how important this is to my program of study, and to my ability to live and work in this world.

I plan on doing forestry management for work. This course is useful in that, for sure, but more, it's useful in life in general. I'll never look at institutions, town hall meetings, media, etc. the same again.
As I mentioned above, the ideas shared in this course changed my whole approach to dealing with complex problems. Not just in environmental conservation, but in my everyday life.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I took it because I knew it would make me a better person, thinker, and environmental worker.
I took this course because I had heard amazing reviews from other students and because I respect Susan.
Heard many things about it - good and bad - wanted to see for myself. Overall am glad I took it.
I wanted more opportunity to think through the policy sciences in a more applied manner. This class was absolutely fabulous.
I heard great things about Dr. Clark and Tim.
I wanted to explore topics in large scale conservation from a true inter disciplinarian. I got a lot more than I bargained for.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Exceeded. And I'm still learning...

To be honest, I did not really know what to expect when I started taking the course. I had just heard really amazing reviews of the course and was excited to learn about conservation from a very different perspective.
Took me about half of the semester to fully understand what was going on, but I learned more than expected. One of my favorite courses so far.
Absolutely. Beyond my expectations, in fact.
Far exceeded them, because I had no idea what I was getting into!
Above and beyond (and also to the sides of) my expectations.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: I really enjoyed the group work in this class. It was all advantageous in my experience.

The group work was fantastic! It gave us an opportunity to discuss the framework, our thoughts and concepts we were confused about in a different setting. Being able to wrestle with questions and concepts with this group really helped me better grasp the framework and how to use it in the future.
The semester long paper/project was a great assignment; learned a lot.
Advantages: get to see other perspectives Disadvantages: Hard to author papers with multiple authors. A little inefficient, timewise. Hard to meet up.
Breaking up large workloads is a positive. But, this can lead to segmentation and specialization that may conflict the goals of collaborative learning.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: I wish every FES student could take this course. If you have the opportunity, I encourage you to do it.

I would advise students to take this course no matter what their focus is. This course teaches you skills, ways of thinking and methods for solution-making that are useful for any discipline. This was a great course to take right before graduating because it was very thought provoking and grounding. It gave us the chance to self-reflect and analyze contexts that we will be in after graduating.
Do it! This is an amazing course that will challenge the way you think about the world.

Come in with an open mind and leave with an expanded one. Taking on this (likely new and unfamiliar) approach can be frustrating at the start, but stick with it. You will begin to see all of the areas in which the policy sciences, and you understanding of them, can open a lot of new areas of understanding, problem orientation, and conflict resolution.
